glance/tests/functional/v2/test_cache_ap.message:
This is a naive question, but is there a timing relationship between a queued image and when we delete it from the queue?

For example, when an image goes into the queue is it automatically removed from the queue after it's cached?

My concern here (if it's even possible) is that this could introduce transient issues in the tests if the queued image is gone by the time we hit line 126. Again, I have no idea if that's even possible, but I wanted to ask for my own knowledge anyway.

In this test we are not caching the image, so it will remain in queued area until we delete it.

Our prefetcher periodic job periodically traverse through this queued folder and picks the image for caching and caches it. As soon as image is picked it is removed from the queued area.

There are some operations in cache middleware which first checks if image is already cached or is it is in process of caching etc.,

[1] https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/image_cache/drivers/sqlite.py#L211

playbooks/functional-test/restricted.yam.message: Is this expected to fail because it hasn't authenticated yet? Or does it bypass the service and talk directly to the disk?

This copies from the disk to the local docker daemon; the registry is not involved.  The "localhost:9000" here doesn't tell skopeo to talk to the registry; instead, that's the name of the image.  So the last line in English is: "write to the local docker daemon and name the image 'localhost:9000/test/image:latest'".  It's very counter intuitive, but naming an image in the local cache with the name of the remote host is the only way to have docker push or pull the image from that host.

nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/te.message: we can remove this too as defined in L188

With this change we are not running the tests with 2.3 microversion which are defined in ServersControllerTestV23. I think idea here is to run all the existing test with new microversion so that we do not regress any other non related API behavior. 

unit tests job take only 12-14 min [1] which I think is not bad so running more test coverage on safer side is no harm. And not sure how much these changes save time, I see job taking 13 min only.

[1] https://zuul.openstack.org/builds?job_name=openstack-tox-py38&project=openstack%2Fnova

> With this change we are not running the tests with 2.3 microversion which are defined in ServersControllerTestV23. I think idea here is to run all the existing test with new microversion so that we do not regress any other non related API behavior. 

Perhaps, but I think that's a bad idea. It's a huge cost and the chances of actually catching something with this are IMO minuscule. We're not even consistent about it as-is: look at how 'ServersControllerTestV226' below doesn't inherit from its predecessor. If nothing else, we've already proven that we haven't regressed on these things to say the tests have been passing for 4-5 years without fail. People shouldn't be messing with these older microversions now.

> unit tests job take only 12-14 min [1] which I think is not bad so running more test coverage on safer side is no harm. And not sure how much these changes save time, I see job taking 13 min only.
> 
> [1] https://zuul.openstack.org/builds?job_name=openstack-tox-py38&project=openstack%2Fnova

That's more than 1 minute saved on *every* *single* *run* though. That add up to a lot of time given the amount of CI runs we do 😄 Our unit tests take too long to run and things like this are wasteful IMO because they don't offer enough extra to justify the run time. I think once we test that behavior is different in microversion N-1 and N then we're doing enough. The result is "good enough" test coverage and a massive reduction in test run time. We make compromises like this all the time, e.g. we don't generate API samples for every possible combination of API requests because that would be insane. This is just another such compromise.

Yeah we were/are not consistent on those testing the "first 2.1, immediate previous, and top microversion" testing but I do comment for that as much as possible for new micorversion. We never know the regressions and one good example of such regressions is 'tag' in 2.37 microversion[1].

and saving just 1 min time in unit test job does not give much benefits from gate perspective where we anyways have to wait for an hr to finish other integration jobs.

FYI these jobs aren't really duplicated as such -- they're required for dib-nodepool-functional-* to work

the opendev-buildset-registry job starts our intermediate container image registry daemon and puts that on hold while the tests run.  the nodepool-build-image-siblings then builds a nodepool container image (with dib, openstacksdk, etc. -- the siblings) and uploads that to the intermediate registry (which is on hold :)

the functional tests then install the nodepool-builder container from the intermediate registry and build images using that container.

so yeah, these are required to run in the pipeline where functional test jobs are running.
Ah, thanks. I felt like something fishy might be going on in there!

tripleoclient/utils.py.message:
whilst correct in terms of openstack the project, according to FIPS-140 "MD5 is not allowed
for use in file digests, which require a SHA-1 hash as the minimum."

If we are aiming for FIPS compliance this is going to need to be removed.

You raise a good point Kevin. That's the reason why I made the original patch.
Unfortunately, the hash computed here is compared with one provided by glance, which is md5.

The optimal way forward would, imho, be to patch glance and tripleoclient. But I'm not sure how we would manage such change when it comes to release etc. If the wrong version of glance was used with wrong version of tripleoclient, we would get failures when comparing the hashes. 

I suppose such a change in glance API[0] would probably require some discussion, as it wouldn't be backward compatible. Unless, we would have glance produce two hashes for each image, and choose depending on the FIPS state. Could that work?

further reading: How can a module be defined, when it includes both FIPS-approved and non-FIPS approved security methods?

  ... when a module is in the "FIPS mode", a non-FIPS approved method shall not be used in
  lieu of a FIPSapproved method (For example, if a module contains both MD5 and SHA-1,
  then when hashing is required in the FIPS mode, SHA-1 shall be used.)...

https://csrc.nist.gov/CSRC/media/Projects/cryptographic-module-validation-program/documents/fips140-2/FIPS1402IG.pdf Section G.6. revised 05/04/2021

So I think the only way forward is to convert this to SHA1.

could an Upgrade step involve re-hashing the images? Though it would more than probably extend the upgrade duration.

Another way would be to support a mix for "some time":
still supports md5, but deprecate it and use sha1 (or higher) for newly added images.

That way, we should be able to make a smooth move toward a more FIPS compliant mode.
I'm going to look into this further, and see what can be done on the glance api side.  We can then decide how we want to proceed here until API changes can be made.  Stay tuned ..
Don't we want to catch the "unknown hash" exception here and have a more graceful crash than the actual full stack trace?

Not saying it's a bad idea. Actually, I've contemplated it myself.

But, this API is used very scarcely. All of the calls are made by either retrieving the hash value from image metadata, or, and this is much more frequent use, by using the new default algo: sha512.

If, and this is very unlikely, images start to come in using invalid algorithm, we don't really have any way to recover, as the hash might as well be a random string from our POV. 

Furthermore, when supplied with wrong hash algorithm, the message from hashlib already contains pretty much all of the info one could want from it.

Trace:
------
>>> hashlib.new("abs")
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.9/hashlib.py", line 160, in __hash_new
    return _hashlib.new(name, data, **kwargs)
ValueError: unsupported hash type

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.9/hashlib.py", line 166, in __hash_new
    return __get_builtin_constructor(name)(data)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.9/hashlib.py", line 123, in __get_builtin_constructor
    raise ValueError('unsupported hash type ' + name)
ValueError: unsupported hash type abs

tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_image.py.message: So what happens if glance has an overcloud image that was uploaded before this client change lands. Is the idea that the user then needs to manually remove the old image and re-upload?

The glance client change that brought different hash algorithms, and effectively deprecated the MD5 from singing perspective, was introduced in Rocky[4]. As I learned from the glance squad, every standard image created since that release should have both attributes set.

As you said, images from before don't have it. This is awkward, as we need to verify the image somehow, and we can't use MD5 for reasons outlined in the commit message. In that case, the user will, indeed, have to replace the image with one that has the attributes set.

But, from what I understand, that sort of thing should happen only rarely, if at all.


[4]https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/glance/rocky.html#new-features

The main point here is how deploy works now, we don't know all nodes that would be deployed at one time (it would be  request sequence). So DHT peers have to discovering new nodes at a given time and peer may or may not provide a list, or only a partial list of peers, which changes during provisioning (and we don't continue seeding after node was deployed, because it's hard to say when all nodes done provisioning).

I'm consider using this extensions when we will accept a bulk of nodes on deploy at same time, so we know all deployed nodes and could effectively control the process.
I think the biggest reason for it is the short lifespan of the deploying IPA.

It would require avoiding the Power-off after cleaning step (on a (randomly) selected node subset) so it might serve the "hottest" image bits. This would be limited by the amount of space in RAM to avoid having to keep the image bits on the drive which was cleaned.

I think that unless you tell it not to, the bittorrent client should download the pieces in a random order, so we should not need to do any random sleeps before deployment.

The aria2c client has two options of interest here. --seed-time allows you to specify an amount of time to seed for after the download is complete. --seed-ratio allows you to specify a seed ratio at which to stop seeding. If both are specified, then if either case is hit seeding will finish. We could use a seed ratio of ~1.0 and a reasonable seed time to trade off responsiveness vs. overall efficiency (30 seconds?). A third mechanism to stop seeding would be to check the tracker or DHT to see if any other peers are downloading.

Of course, I agree that this all needs to be backed up experimentally.

The attraction of BitTorrent in this use case is that it places less load on the control plane through the creation of an ad-hoc deployment data delivery network.  Concurrent deployment of large numbers of nodes with the same image (our use case) benefits from this.  You can't (or don't want to) size a fan-out style of deployment to the largest scenario.

nova/compute/api.py.message: This is the case specific to bug 1836754 where the server is being deleted while building.

So _local delete happens if the server is being deleted while the compute host the server is assigned to is considered down. Race can happen between the compute and the api if the compute is not dead just inaccessible from the api perspective. In that case both the compute and the api can manipulate allocations in parallel. 

If we know that a user initiated server delete is always superior to any allocation manipulation done by the compute on that server in the meantime. Then sure we can force the delete here. If the allocation manipulation on the compute side always uses consumer generations (I think it does) then that manipulation might fail due to conflict which feels OK as nothing needs to be done on a deleted server allocation wise anymore.

I think one of you mentioned the case yesterday about deleting the allocation from the api, but as the compute racing with this delete the compute might re-create the allocation. Do we have safeguard against it?
We hit this in a number of different paths though, right? Like, what's a "soft" delete?

A few things here:

1. We also do the delete in the API if the server is shelved offloaded since it doesn't have a compute host. It wouldn't have allocations in that case either though...

2. In what scenarios is the compute service down from the API perspective but is actually running and mucking with allocations? The resource tracker doesn't update allocations anymore. Are you thinking of like some weird scenario where a port with resource requests is detached from the server while the server is being deleted at the same time? If so, we likely can't get to the compute to do the detach if it's down.

3. Where would the compute re-create the allocations while the API is trying to delete them because it's doing a local delete b/c the service group API says the compute service is down? Yesterday I found latent bug 1848343 which is about re-creating and leaking allocations for a deleted server during resize/cold migrate rollback, but I don't think that's the same issue here.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: In this case we're deleting the server so why would we need to use consumer generations?

I'm not too worried about the edge case of a soft-deleted instance being reclaimed while the periodic is running to clean it up and the user migrating the server. Soft-delete is not enabled by default and even if you do enable it you'd still have to hit a tight window to hit the issue you're talking about. However, if you feel we shouldn't force the allocation delete when calling this from the soft delete reclaim periodic, then we could plumb a kwarg down to the method to determine what should happen with allocation cleanup.

This is called from 

* _init_instance() at compute restart. There we only trigger this if the server already in DELETING state. I guest the API does not allow any lifecycle operation on a server in such state. So it is OK to force the delete.

* _reclaim_queued_deletes() periodically to clean up timed out soft deleted servers. Soft deleted servers can be restored. So there is a potential race between restore coming from the user and the periodic cleanup happening in the compute. Restore does not manipulate allocations it simply assumes that the allocations exists. So _reclaim_queued_deletes and restore cannot race on placement. There is a potential race still. The _reclaim_queued_deletes() queries the soft deleted instances and then goes into a loop to delete them if they are old. While this loop progresses the user can restore the server from the list of servers being reclaimed, and then start another lifecycle operation on this serer, like migrate it which does resource manipulation on the server. So _theoretically_ we can have a race on allocation manipulation here. And Blindly deleting the allocation in this is the wrong choice. I would simply fail the reclaim instead.

* do_terminate_instance during user initiated delete. I think here we are safe to force the delete.
In this case the build failed and we're not rescheduling.
In this case the build failed on this host and we're going to try to reschedule.
Unshelve failed so the instance isn't on a host so it shouldn't have allocations.

nova/scheduler/client/report.py.message: Everything in this condition is essentially what this method used to do before https://review.opendev.org/#/c/591597/.

This one will still be subject to the race. And this is an example where we *either* want to

- eliminate that race (force=True); or
- widen the window, perhaps by GETting the generations outside of this loop. Not sure how much that really helps, though.

In either case we still have the problem of the other operation coming in and creating allocations after this deletion goes through, which would cause _delete_provider to fail.

Currently we hit this from two places:
- When we're deleting the compute service. In this case I hope we've disabled it first and prevented any other operations from starting -- but what if that operation had already started by the time we disabled? That operation would presumably fail out eventually, and that might clean up the allocations, but the compute service deletion still failed (leaving the service in a partially-deleted state? can you redrive the deletion?)
- Removing orphaned ironic nodes (which presumably have been shuffled to another hashring). In this case any other in-flight operation on that node ought to fail soon and (hopefully) clean up, deleting its allocations. The node provider might still be orphaned this iteration (because _delete_provider fails), but would get cleaned up on the next periodic.

ceph-client/templates/bin/pool/_init.sh..message: what is the (expected) difference between pg_num_min and ${PG_NUM_MIN}? doesn't seem like we are even checking pg_num_min anymore?

pg_num_min = value that ceph is currently using (when the autoscaler is enabled this will currently have a value of 1 downstream and 8 upstream)

PG_NUM_MIN = value specified in overrides (currently 1 when the autoscaler is enabled but is being increased to 32 in a separate downstream PS)

So ... for sites that currently use the autoscaler the expected difference during an upgrade (BF) will be 31. 

Once all sites using the autoscaler are using the value specified in the overrides there will be no expected difference (unless we decide to change PG_NUM_MIN again).

I'm also not sure that encoding all that stuff in a policy rule is really the right place to do this. I can imagine that getting pretty long and hairy.

tacker/vnfm/infra_drivers/kubernetes/k8s.message:
Just to be sure, I'd like to question.
The `service` parameter is must parameter in `V1APIServiceSpec`, but the type of `service` parameter is `ApiregistrationV1ServiceReference`. Does the `ApiregistrationV1ServiceReference` need to be define in `must_param`?

Does not need to be defined.
The required parameter of an object defined in must_param is an attribute that must be assigned when the object is initialized.
For example, for `V1APIServiceSpec`, it has an attribute of `service`, and then only need to assign a value to the service to pass the initialization detection of k8s. The category of its `service` attribute is `ApiregistrationV1ServiceReference`. For this object, it does not have any attributes that must be assigned, so there is no need to define its initialization.
Thank you for your response. I understood.

test/unit/container/test_sharder.py.message:
Just out of curiousity, what whould happen when all these roots replicate together:
  
  dict(delete_timestamp=T(old recreate),
     put_timestamp=T(recently PUT),
     status_changed_at=T(recently PUT),
     storage_policy_index=3),

In this case both the reconciler and shards would do the right thing. _and_ the shards current code, would have got there first I guess.

I think status_changed_at would take a new value if the SPI is updated: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/bc5f4c061122aee5965cfb055beb3cb079073536/swift/container/replicator.py#L66-L86

It's weird though, AFAICT, old recreate wins for policy index and delete timestamp but recently put wins for put_timestamp.

I wonder if we have/need some tests to prove our understanding?

OK, think I see, according to that code status_changed_at will be updated if the SPI is different and needs to change.

But it also seems to indicate that we don't do a sync of status_changed_at during replication, only created_at, delete, and put timestamps. Which seems to indicate to me that the status_changed_at is used more of a 'local to the replica' last_changed_at. So maybe doesn't really count when it comes to replaying events. So if we take it out of the equiation. Then I'd expect no matter how we replay these root's on a single container we'd always get the same, if we only ever based on latest timestamps (which we're currently not doing in the reconciler because it takes latest first unless there is a recreated one, then that wins):

  delete_timestamp = T1
  put_timestamp = T2
  created_at = T0 (or maybe T1 as it might have updated the created_at at thre recreate)
  storage_policy_index = 3

Yeah, I think we need some tests and I also love the idea of your axiom 😊

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I99a49b107b1872ddf83d1d8497a26a8d728feb07 specifically right?

Yes, that is the patch that implement the extension. However neutron already landed the patch that defines the extension [1] so we can depend on the name of the extension already in this and subsequent patches to detect the new extension. 

After we land both rejection patches (this and the next one) we are safe from nova perspective as we handled the new extension. Then this patch series gradually enables the use of that extension from nova perspective as implementation is added. 

If neutron does not have this extension (not merged or merged but disable by config) then nova automatically falls back supporting the old extension (port-resource-request) so we are not breaking the legacy scenarios.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-lib/+/803905

Yes,
This bug has to do with the commit:
https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/config/+/788815/5/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/manager.py - Line 5188

There is a comparison (fs.get('name') in drbd_fs_resized)):

fs.get('name') returns 'database', while in the drbd_fs_resized list, the returned value was 'pgsql'

This difference only ocurred when trying to resize the database, all the other controllers had proper names, so all other controllerfs could be resized without any problems. These names can be seen in the constants.py file, line 553:

# DRBD File Systems
DRBD_PLATFORM = 'platform'
DRBD_PGSQL = 'pgsql'
DRBD_EXTENSION = 'extension'
DRBD_DC_VAULT = 'dc-vault'
DRBD_ETCD = 'etcd'
DRBD_DOCKER_DISTRIBUTION = 'docker-distribution'

# File system names
FILESYSTEM_NAME_BACKUP = 'backup'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_PLATFORM = 'platform'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_CINDER = 'cinder'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_DATABASE = 'database'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_SCRATCH = 'scratch'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_DOCKER = 'docker'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_DOCKER_DISTRIBUTION = 'docker-distribution'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_EXTENSION = 'extension'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_ETCD = 'etcd'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_DC_VAULT = 'dc-vault'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_KUBELET = 'kubelet'
FILESYSTEM_NAME_IMAGE_CONVERSION = 'image-conversion'

Only DRBD_PGSQL had a different value in relation to the FILESYSTEM_NAME_* constants, and when doing that comparison, it didn't detect the database resizing, even though the resizing was successful. Therefore, the alarm was never cleared. By changing this constant value, which is used only in the resize method, the resize was detected properly and the alarm was cleared.

releasenotes/notes/add-reserved-share-fr.message: Perhaps this is something that could go in the documentation, and here only mention that a new option was added to help Manila to place shares that are being created from snapshot. In this way, we won't give much details here and we can have more details in the documentation :)

There's an upgrade impact to this; currently, whether shares are provisioned from snapshots or not, we set aside  a reserved_share_percentage amount and ensure we don't cross into that - however - if existing deployers upgrade to this release and forget to set reserved_share_from_snapshot_percentage, we'll default this to 0 and hence lose the reservation that was previously being set aside, 

Instead of defaulting to 0 when the value isn't set, can we default to the value of "reserved_share_percentage"? 
If we do that, we don't break people that 1) don't want to reserve space for snapshot-clones separately from normal shares, and 2) forget to set this option, but are relying on "reserved_share_percentage".

cinder/db/sqlalchemy/models.py.message: given the code below and explanation supporting it, we can remove this part.
I think this should be default=None for use_quota_online_data_migration()?

The way the code works this will not be used for old resources that were created before we add the use_quota DB fields.

The DB migration creates a new column, but you can see in file `cinder/db/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/145_add_use_quota_fields.py` that it doesn't set a default, and since the new column is nullable it will be set to NULL/None.

So after running the DB migration all existing resources will have a NULL/None value, which is what the online migration code looks for (both in the OVO and the cinder-manage command) to write an actual value.

So for this release `use_quota` will have 2 states and 3 values so we can tell when a resource has valid data: Unset (value is None) and Set (value is False or True).
In the next release all resources will have a valid value in `use_quota`, and that's why we have to make the `nullable` to False, to make sure it always have a valid value.

In this release old resources will start with an undefined value in `use_quota` and it will be set when we save it using the OVO or when we run the online data migrations.

For new resources the value will be usually set by the caller of the resource creation, but if it's not set there it will be either set by the OVO code or this default value.

In other words, this default only takes place when we use ORM instances and don't set a value, but the DB migration doesn't use it.

nova/objects/compute_node.py.message: Can we make the extra and unusual behavior of the object delete explicit? I mean there is now a logic that nova only deletes ComputeNode object from the DB if the value of the ComputeNode.host field in the object is matching with the value of the corresponding column of the DB.

Hm, I think this is a fair point. If I'm understanding correctly, I believe we do have some prior art here with the Instance object [1]:

        if not self.obj_attr_is_set('host') or not self.host:
            # NOTE(danms): If our host is not set, avoid a race
            constraint = db.constraint(host=db.equal_any(None))
        else:
            constraint = None

        try:
            db_inst = db.instance_destroy(self._context, self.uuid,
                                          constraint=constraint,
                                          hard_delete=hard_delete)
            self._from_db_object(self._context, self, db_inst)
        except exception.ConstraintNotMet:
            raise exception.ObjectActionError(action='destroy',
                                              reason='host changed')

where we will add a host field constraint on the delete query. Unless I'm missing something, we could do the same thing for ComputeNode and raise ObjectActionError if we get ConstraintNotMet from the DB layer. And then handle that in the compute manager. Doing this we would add a constraint=None kwarg to the compute_node_delete method instead of adding a host arg.

What do you think?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/dab4ec1a534d4774e61a24cdace0f3491788e4e7/nova/objects/instance.py#L646

As the race we are fixing here is happening during a periodic task we cannot make the not-deletion explicit to the user, we can only log it. However this is a generic destroy() method that might be later used not just from the periodic task but from some user facing action. There I would expect to get an error response if the deletion failed due to host differences. So I think what melwitt suggests is a good direction. Raise from the db method if there is an unmet constraint, handle that in the periodic now by ignoring / logging. Then later when somebody starts using this destory() method will need to explicitly deal with the exception.

I saw virt-customize faster and more reliable when running on the very slow upstream CI nodes (not having nested virtualization).

Hmm, but what if we want to create 2+ VMs with trunk ports? Trunk subports inside each VM should be configured with different static IP address. I omitted the code that sets subport ip addresses since it not needed for the initial test but in case we want to ping a subport we'll have to find a way to set the ip. It should be permanent so setting by 'ip' command via ssh does not look good. My idea was to use modified cloud-init settings for each VM. Another option is to modify network scripts via ssh.
We should figure out to merge this user data with the one of base classes merge configured elements.

Well, officially Ussuri does not support py27 anymore, though yes, this should have landed earlier (and get released earlier if this was needed). Anyway, if we consider that stable/ussuri will transition to Extended Maintenance and there is no open patches against stable/ussuri we can safely expect that there won't be any need for a release until the transition. So I'll abandon this release patch (so 4.10.0 release will be tagged as EM, which is I think fine).

ansible/group_vars/all.yml.message:
can this be a password generated instead if a sample hardcode of a string?

Will it be backwards compatible when upgrading? If not, please add a release note notifying the value of this should match their value

It is *not* backwards compatible when upgrading. It must always match the value for whatever cloud is being deployed.
So, for any given deployment, it needs to *never change*. I don't know how to generate it *once* in a safe way. If there's a good way to do that, then yes, that would be ideal. Is there?

This should go to passwords.yml - you can inspire here https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/455628.

1. You can find there usage of variable {{ osprofiler_secret }} in services templates.
2. Define it in etc/kolla/passwords.yml
3. Include it in kolla_ansible/cmd/genpwd.py 

Also, from my perspective of view this behavious should be configurable - so config will be rendered based on some variable - something as "enable_amphora_secure" which should be "no" by default as it is now.

storlets/agent/daemon/server.py.message: Is this safe for any case?

I believe so this operation is cancel so we expect the process is immediately stops.
Actually we trigger this cancel operation when the middleware times out during reading data from agent side and the middleware no longer consumes data from middleware in that case.

IIUC we have not implemented signal handler for SIGTERM so in that case SIGTERM results in the same situation. So nothing is changed by this switch effectively.

src/c/sbus/sbus.h.message: This feels like a breaking API change... I was expecting something more like -1 on error, 1 on timeout, 0 on success (which preserves the current notion of "success").

The pros of this change is that we can align this return code with the ones of select function we call inside sbus_listen.

In addition, we generally have 'if rc < 0' instead of 'if not rc' to check error, which follows the way in kernel, I don't think it is not so breaking to replace success return code by 1.
hmm... in linux world, IIRC, 0 is usually used as success code so the change would not be intuitive.
This follows the return code of select. Another option is to use -2 for timeout and 0 for success but I hesitate adding something we define by ourselves.

I see. The return code may be 0 when the timeout expired.

https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/select.2.html#RETURN_VALUE

I'm not sure the "may be" can be assumed we hav 0 always tho.

storlets/gateway/gateways/docker/runtime.message: auto_remove seems good idea. However, it might have side-effect that we cannot make a hot-node (i.e. re-use running images) anymore, right?

You are correct. When auto_remove is enabled then a container is deleted when it terminates(likely because of timeout). So when a next request comes then we need to spawn a new container here.
However in general spawning a new container is a light-waight operation because a container images are already in this node.
